awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Effects of emotion on hippocampal representations and memory retrieval
awd_abstract_narration:
Emotions have been shown to have profound and long-lasting effects on memory. In particular, negative emotional memories can remain salient even years after a traumatic episode occurs. In some cases, such as in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), traumatic memories are improperly retrieved and often interfere with daily life. The hippocampus, an area involved in memory formation, plays an important role in learned fear of a context. However, the specific ways in which emotional information is stored in hippocampal subregions are not well understood.This project will investigate the roles of the dorsal and ventral regions of the hippocampus in the encoding and consolidation of fear memories by combining in vivo recordings in freely moving mice with genetic, computational, and behavioral tools to evaluate how the firing properties of hippocampal neurons change over time as animals form and retrieve emotional memories. The expectation is that contextual representations in the dorsal and the ventral hippocampus will change as animals learn that a specific location is fearful. These experiments will be critical to our understanding of how episodic fear memories are encoded along the longitudinal hippocampal axis. 

The broader impact of this project will be to expand interest in the field of neuroscience by enhancing local infrastructure for education through contributions to the Neuroscience in Your World program organized by the Franklin Institute and the University of Pennsylvania. Also, the tools developed for this program will be linked to the Resources for Science Learning at http://www.fi.edu, an educational website that welcomes 1 million visits per month.

por.por_cntn:
Emotional responses to danger have profound and long-lasting effects on memory. In contrast with everyday recollections, emotional memories remain salient even years after a traumatic episode occurs. The enduring quality of emotional memories can be advantageous because it allows an organism to avoid dangerous situations. However, when traumatic memories are continuously retrieved, they can be debilitating. The retrieval of fearful memories in inappropriate contexts is a trademark of several anxiety disorders and phobias. Therefore, understanding how emotions affect the formation of contextual representations in the brain is of fundamental importance. Abnormalities in the hippocampus, a region involved in memory formation, have been associated with the etiology of several anxiety disorders. The hippocampus is comprised by a dorsal and ventral region, which appear to specialize in spatial processing and emotional information, respectively. However, it was unknown how representations in these areas  changed in the long-term following dangerous situations. This question was investigated combining in vivo electrophysiological recordings along with computational, behavioral, and pathway-selective chemogenetic tools. We found that in the dorsal hippocampus emotional memories generated spatial representations that were long lasting, mimicking the enduring quality of emotional memories. However, these dorsal representations changed when the animals learned that the context no longer signaled danger. Importantly, different aspects of the spatial context were differentially encoded, depending on whether the animal was oriented or lost in the context. Interestingly, cells in the ventral hippocampus were much more heterogeneous than those in the dorsal area, with some displaying spatial properties and other responding to the emotional valence of the context. Moreover, although at the single cell level the representations in the ventral region were very large and appeared less precise than those in the dorsal area, spatial information at the population level contained accurate spatial information in both  regions. Neural network modeling suggested that the redundancy in spatial coding along the longitudinal hippocampal axis may allow the hippocampus to overcome the conflict between memory interference and generalization inherent in neural network memory. This idea was further investigated usinga histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor, a drug that increases transcription through acetylation of histone proteins. In the dorsal area, the HDAC inhibitor increased fear to a dangerous context, whereas in the ventral region it led to fear generalization, corroborating the modeling results. Since different cells in the ventral hippocampus send projections to the prefrontal cortex and amygdala, two regions of the fear learning circuit, it was also critical to investigate the role of selective ventral projections.  Specific activation of ventral projections to the prelimbic cortex, a region involved in the expression of fear, led to generalization of extinction. All these results were reported in 10 peer-refiewed publications. In summary, the scientific portion of this proposal showed the following results: A) Spatial representations in the dorsal hippocampus are modulated by the emotional state of the animal.  B) Although ventral representations are broadly tuned, they contain precise spatial information. C) The spatial gradient observed along the longitudinal axis appears to provide an important mnemonic advantage. These results shed light into the properties of the dorsal and ventral regions in the processing of contextual and emotional events.

The main goal of the educational plan of this proposal was to increase critical thinking and passion for neuroscience by stimulating students of different ages, providing opportunities to underrepresented minorities and women, and disseminating tools for educational programs. This has been achieved through the educational tools developed for the Brain Exhibit at the Franklyn Museum, training and mentoring undergraduate and graduate students, and reaching out the community through podcasts, public radio talks, and public symposia. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The overall intellectual merit of this proposal relied on using a multidisciplinary approach combining behavioral, electrophysiological, computational, and chemogenetic tools to investigate how emotional and spatial inputs are integrated along the hippocampal longitudinal axis. The merit of the educational plan was that it had a very strong dissemination component, which ensured a broad impact both locally and nationally on a large sector of the population

BROADER IMPACT: The experiments described in this proposal clarified the contributions of the dorsal and ventral regions in the encoding of spatial and emotional information. The educational plan outlined in this proposal fostered critical thinking in college and graduate students, increase neuroscience knowledge in high school students, and provided tools for science educators across the United States.
